Ian Badcoe wrote:

>Hi,
>	The other feature I am currently using in SLEAT, and I only started using 
>it because I have a bloat problem, is periodic trimming of dead-wood.  This 
>is very like Colin's "phased search who'se exact name escapes me right now" 
>  
>
Actually I think that's what it's called.

>	The way the works is simple, ever 5 or 10-thousand cycles, I iterate 
>through every individual employing the hi-fi design principle.  (I call it 
>this because of a story I read in some book, where the engineer says: "I 
>design the perfect hi-fi, management take components out until it stops 
>working, then they put the last component back and sell it").
>  
>
In the software industry we just sell the product broken. That's 
probably a Dilbert cartoon I expect.

>	Basically each deletable feature (chromosome, rule or gene) of a genome is 
>numbered and I run through them all, temporarily deleting them, 
>recalculating the fitness, and then only putting them back if the fitness 
>was reduced.
>
>	To make this run in reasonable time, I have had to employ some heuristics.
>
>[...] When trimming dead wood, I try trimming each 
>feature the first two times it comes up (using its birth-date, the current 
>cycle and the known frequency of trimming phases) and if it survives both 
>of those, I assume it is important and I do not try to trim it again until 
>the 10th trim-cycle after its birth.
>  
>
Yeh I like it, oh was this the bit that was my idea? Actually 
SharpNEAT's GUI has an 'Enable weight fixing' check box, which basically 
means fix any connection that survived a pruning phase, permanently. 
Subsequently both the pruning algorithm and the weight mutation routines 
avoid these fixed connections. Dropping the fixed state after a few gens 
sounds like a good idea, although I was thinking about a more thorough 
revision of how this system worked, perhaps using connection 'hardness' 
values that change over time and which tell us how often we should 
perturb a weight or consider it for pruning. This I think is something 
else that has been discussed before, anyway more on that another day.

>	Anyway, this seems to keep the bload right down and also, I often seem to 
>get fitness bursts just after trimming, which I attribute to cross-over 
>become far more effective between individuals with no wasted genes...
>  
>

Yes that is a common observation of mine also. It may be crossover, in 
my write-up I think I attributed this phenomenon to the deletion of 
'deleterious structures' or something like that, basically connections 
that feed useless noise into networks.

Colin.
